abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Enterprise
            Institutional Development Project for Government of Congo
            (GOC) were as follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, project
            suitability was uncertain, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the transfer of
            PE management responsibilities to interim administrators and
            private liquidators was instrumental to improve these
            enterprises' management and financial control and
            reduce line ministries' interference into their
            operations, prior to their privatization or liquidation. The
            competitive selection of private liquidators also improved
            the credibility and transparency of these operations. In
            retrospect, the project was overly ambitious given
            GOC's implementation and absorptive capacity. Extension
            of its closing date proved to be effective for realization
            of some of Project's objectives and at the same time
            provided adequate support for the preparation of the
            follow-up Privatization and Capacity Building Project.
            Availability of resources to address the financial costs of
            reforms is critical to the success of TA projects. The
            Public Enterprise Institutional Development Project (PEIDP)
            had little impact in key areas, including banking sector
            reform, PE cross-debt settlement and staff reduction, mainly
            because of Government's budgetary constraints. The
            Project could have been more effective if a strategy to fund
            the costs and obligations of these reforms had been
            established at the beginning. These issues should have been
            appraised during the Project design and preparation.
